description: From Middle English consecucioun (“attainment”), from Latin consecutio (“effect, proper sequence, attainment”), from past participle of consequor (“to follow, result, reach”).

entries.meaning: (archaic) A following, or sequel; actual or logical dependence.
examples: Some consecutions are so intimately and evidently connexed to or found in the premises, that the conclusion is attained, and without any thing of ratiocinative progress

entries.meaning: (obsolete) A succession or series of any kind.
(logic) The relation of consequent to antecedent.
(music) A succession of similar intervals in harmony.
